III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to
Section requirements; staff qualifications.
Description Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff qualifications
1

(4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Allegation #1: A staff member had physical contact with a youth
in the form of hugging and kissing the youth on the forehead.
Allegation #2: Staff member was making inappropriate sexual
comments to Youth A.
Investigation Interviews
Allegation #1
On 7/17/25 Telephone contact was made with Complainant. No
additional concerns were noted.
The following interviews were completed at The Sanctuary on
7/18/2025, unless otherwise noted.
An interview was completed with Youth A. She reported having a
good relationship with Staff 1. She further stated she was “tired”
of being asked about Staff 1. She confirmed that Staff 1 had
hugged her before “a couple of times”. She stated that it
happened months ago and that Staff 1 or no other staff are
allowed to hug youth in the program. Youth A described the hug
as “being in a way of comfort”. She denied that she ever felt
uncomfortable or that she felt the hug was “sexual” in nature. She
described the hug as a “side hug”. Youth A reported that Staff 1
was told by other staff that the hugging was inappropriate and that
it had to stop. When asked if Staff 1 had ever kissed her, she
responded “Hell No!!”. She followed up and stated that she
recalled Staff 1 had kissed her on the forehead on one occasion
but again described it as a gesture of comfort and denied that it
was sexual in nature. She recalled that she was sitting in the
living room and Staff 1 walked in, Youth A reached out for a hug
and Staff 1 hugged her back and kissed her on the forehead.
Youth A denied feeling uncomfortable. Youth A denied seeing
Staff 1 kiss any other youth. She confirmed that she has seen
Staff 1 hug other youth. She denied that any youth had expressed
to her feeling uncomfortable after hugging Staff 1. Youth A was
unable or unwilling to provide names of youth that she witnessed
hugging Staff 1. Youth A denied that Staff 1 has ever made
inappropriate or sexual comments to her.
An interview was completed with Staff 2. She reported that on
7/10/25 she was in the living room area of the facility with Youth A,
2

Youth B, and Youth C. She reported they were watching TV and
Staff 1 arrived. She reported feeling like the “vibe shifted” when
Staff 1 came in. Youth A was on the phone with a family member
and Staff 2 recalled hearing Youth A make a statement about
someone being “in her space”. Staff 2 reported that Youth B
began stating he “felt uncomfortable around Staff 1. He did not
indicate a reason why he felt uncomfortable. Staff 2 reported that
Youth A began to share about a time Staff 1 came into her
bedroom and “hugged and kissed her” but stated it was not on the
mouth. Staff 2 recalled that it sounded “weird and awkward” to
her. Staff 2 further reported that both Youth B and Youth C
indicated feeling uncomfortable around Staff 1. Staff 2 stated she
discussed what the youth were saying with Staff 3 and then they
called Program Manager and informed him of what the youth were
saying. Staff 2 denied that she called centralized intake. She
stated Program Manager told her that they would do an
investigation. Staff 2 denied seeing Staff 1 kiss Youth A or any
other youth. Staff 2 denied seeing Staff 1 hug Youth A or any
other youth. Staff 2 denied hearing Staff 1 make inappropriate
sexual comments to Youth A or any other youth.
On 7/21/2025 a telephone call was made to assigned DHHS
Specialist. She confirmed that case had been assigned to her
and law enforcement had been advised of the allegations. Case
interviews were discussed, and a follow up appointment was
scheduled for 7/30/2025.
On 7/23/2025 an email was sent to Chief Administrator (CA) and
Program Manager. They were advised of assigned special
investigation and the allegations of the investigation. A request
was made for agency policy, incident reports and information
regarding discipline for staff regarding the hugging or kissing of
staff.
The following interviews were completed at The Sanctuary on
7/30/2025 along with DHHS Specialist, unless otherwise
noted.
An interview was completed with Program Manager. He denied
having any concerns with Staff 1. He confirmed that “a couple of
months ago” he addressed the issue of boundaries and physical
touch with agency youth. A request was made to forward me a
copy of the documentation. Program Manager also confirmed that
Staff 2 contacted him on 7/10 and advised of concerns that had
been expressed by the youth. Program Manager stated that prior
3

to notification of this incident, he had no knowledge of staff
continuing to engage in hugging and kissing of agency youth.
An interview was completed with Youth B. He reported that
Youth A would tell him about how Staff 1 had kissed her and had
her phone number. He also reported Youth A told him that Staff 1
would discuss inappropriate things with her. He stated he had
proof via text message but was unable to provide it upon request.
Youth B denied that he had ever seen Staff 1 inappropriately
touch Youth A but reported always seeing them “cuddling on the
bed or couch”. Youth B denied ever reporting the concerns to
other staff. Youth B was very vocal about his dislike of Staff 1,
indicating that she was rude and disrespectful.
An interview was completed with Staff 4. She confirmed having
worked shifts with Staff 1 but stated she did not work with her
regularly. She denied youth have expressed concerns to her
about Staff 1. She also denied seeing inappropriate contact
between Staff 1 and agency youth.
An interview was completed with Staff 5. He denied that he has
worked with Staff 1 or that youth have expressed any concerns
regarding Staff 1 to him. He also denied seeing or having
knowledge of Staff 1 hugging or kissing youth placed in the
program.
On 7/30/2025 an in-person interview was completed with Staff 1
at her home. Staff 1 reported having a good relationship with
Youth A. She confirmed that she would hug Youth A, as she
would also do to other youth in the past. She denied the hugs
were sexual in nature and reported that she stopped doing it once
the Program Manager discussed it with her three or four months
ago. Staff 1 also admitted to kissing Youth A on the forehead, but
also denied it being in a sexual manner. She described it as a
“nurturing” gesture. Staff 1 admitted that she “broke the rules”.
She further stated that when she was told it seemed that she was
“favoring” Youth A, she began to try to distance herself. Staff 1
reported that all staff would hug the youth. She denied that she
was attempting to groom Youth A. On 08/08/2025 and
08/25/2025 telephone call attempts were made to Staff 1 without
success.
On 08/06/2025 a telephone interview was completed with Chief
Administrator. She advised that Program Manager confirmed
having discussed with Staff 1 and other staff agency policy
surrounding physical contact with youth. She further stated she
4

was unable to provide the exact date as there was no written
documentation of the discussion.
On 08/06/2025 a telephone interview was completed with Youth
C. She denied any concerns while placed at Sanctuary. She
stated she felt safe and denied ever feeling uncomfortable. She
confirmed that Staff 1 has hugged her but again denied that it
made her feel uncomfortable. Youth C denied that Staff 1 ever
kissed her or made any inappropriate comments to her during her
placement. Youth C denied seeing Staff 1 kiss or hug other youth
and denied hearing Staff 1 make inappropriate comments to other
youth.
On 08/07/2025 an interview was completed with Staff 3 at The
Sanctuary by DCWL Consultant 2. Staff confirmed she has
worked shifts with Staff 1. She shared that she experienced
significant issues with Staff 1’s interactions with youth, particularly
around boundary concerns. She confirmed observing Staff 1
frequently hug Youth A often. She reported once observing Staff
1 and Youth A sitting closely together on the couch in the living
room area of Sanctuary. Youth A was resting her head in Staff 1’s
lap while they watched television. Staff 3 reported that Youth A
seemed to be uncomfortable once she noticed Staff 3 was in the
area. Staff 3 recalled hearing Staff 1 state, “staff won’t say
anything”. Staff 3 reported that Staff 1 appeared nurturing toward
all the youth in the program, but over time, she seemed to spend
the majority of her time specifically with Youth A. Staff 3 stated
she reported her concerns to Program Manager and eventually
requested a shift change because she no longer wanted to work
alongside Staff 1. Staff 3 also stated that to her knowledge other
staff shared their concerns regarding Staff 1 with the Program
Manager.
On 08/08/2025 a DHHS Closing Case Conference was held. At
the writing of this report, the DHHS investigation was closed with
no findings of abuse or neglect.
Allegation #2
On 07/18/2025 an interview was completed with Youth A at The
Sanctuary. She denied that Staff 1 made inappropriate sexual
comments toward her or about her. She denied that Staff 1 would
discuss her personal relationship involving her husband in front of
her.
5

On 07/18/2025 an interview was held with Staff 2. She denied
knowledge of inappropriate/sexual comments made by Staff 1
toward Youth A.
On 7/30/2025 an interview of Youth B was completed at The
Sanctuary. He reported being told by Youth A that Staff 1 would
say inappropriate things to her and make inappropriate comments
to her. Youth B reported that Youth A told him that Staff 1 would
discuss the sex life of her husband with her. Youth B stated he
had proof via text message but was unable to provide it upon
request.
On 07/30/2025 an interview was completed with Staff 1 at her
home. She denied speaking with Youth A regarding her personal
life and her husband. She also denied making any inappropriate
or sexual comments to Youth A or any other youth at the agency.
On 08/06/2025 a telephone interview was completed with Youth
C. She denied knowledge of any inappropriate comments made
by Staff 1 to Youth A.
On 08/07/2025 interviews were completed with Staff 4, Staff 5,
Youth D and Staff 6 by DCWL Consultant 2. They all denied
knowledge of Staff 1 making inappropriate/sexual comments to
Youth A.
Documents Reviewed
Lighthouse Employees Policies and Procedures – Code of
Ethical Conduct
The Code of Ethical Conduct sets forth beliefs and ethical
principles and values to which staff members and volunteers shall
aspire to and by which their actions and decisions can be judged.
LIGHTHOUSE practices a zero-tolerance policy for intentional
illegal and/or unethical behavior. Unintentional acts that may be
perceived or construed as possible illegal and/or unethical
behavior will result in disciplinary action commensurate to the act.
C. Conflict of Interest
LIGHTHOUSE staff should be alert to and avoid conflicts of
interest that interfere with the exercise of professional discretion
and impartial judgment. LIGHTHOUSE staff should inform the CEO
and clients when a real or potential conflict of interest arises and
take reasonable steps to resolve the issue in a manner that makes
the clients’ interests primary and protects the clients’ interests to
the greatest extent possible.
6

Staff should not take any unfair advantages of any professional
relationships or exploit others to further their personal, political, or
business interests.
Staff should not engage in dual or multiple relationships with
clients or former clients due to a risk of exploitation or potential
harm to the client.
Staff should take steps to protect clients. Staff are responsible for
setting clear, appropriate, and culturally sensitive boundaries.
D. Staff-Client Relationship—Sexual Conduct
Staff should under no circumstances engage in sexual activity or
sexual contact with clients. Staff members should not engage in
sexual activity or sexual contact with clients’ relatives or other
individuals with whom clients maintain a close personal
relationship (as in financial or familial) when there is risk of
exploitation or potential harm to the client. Such relationships
have the potential to be harmful to the client and may make it
difficult for personnel and the client to maintain appropriate
professional boundaries. LIGHTHOUSE staff—not the client or
their relatives or other individuals with whom the client maintains
a personal relationship—assume the full burden for setting clear
and appropriate boundaries. Staff should under no circumstances
engage in sexual activity or sexual contact with former clients.
Lighthouse Incident Report Form
Incident report form is dated for 07/11/2025 was completed by
Program Manager. It documented that on 7/11/25 it was reported
to Program Manager that Staff 1 had physical contact with Youth
A in the form of hugging and a kiss on the forehead. It was also
reported by Staff 2 that inappropriate sexual comments were
made by Staff 1 to Youth A. Based on these reports, Youth B and
Youth C reported feeling uncomfortable around Staff 1.
Personnel File of Staff 1
Staff 1 is no longer employed by Sanctuary. Her employment was
terminated effective 07/23/2025 for failure to comply with agency
policy. Staff 1 did not have any disciplinary action in her
personnel file and was up to date on all of her training as of June
2025.
Facility Tour
On 7/18/2025 a tour of the agency was completed. There were no
areas of concern noted relative to the physical structure of the
facility.
7

Analysis Allegation #1: At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency
was found to be in compliance with the licensing rule. It was
confirmed that Staff 1 engaged in hugging and a kiss of Youth A
on the forehead, however it was not assessed or reported to be in
a sexual manner. It has not been assessed that Staff 1 did not
have the ability to perform the duties of her position.
Allegation #2: At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency
was found to be in compliance with the licensing rule. There was
no evidence to support allegations that Staff 1 made inappropriate
sexual comments to Youth A.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement.
Section Rule 109. (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
Description program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following: (c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,

Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Allegation #1
Staff A had physical contact with Youth A in the form of hugging
and a kiss on the forehead.
Allegation #2
Agency staff is having telephone and social medica contact with
youth.
Investigation Allegation #1
Interview
On 7/18/2025 an interview was held with Youth A at The
Sanctuary. She confirmed that Staff 1 would often hug her (which
she described as a side hug) and on one occasion Staff 1 kissed
her on her forehead. Youth A reported always feeling comfortable
and described the hugs and kiss on the forehead in a nurturing
manner.
On 07/30/2025 an interview was held with Staff 1 at her home in
Southfield, MI. Staff 1 confirmed that she would engage in
hugging of youth in the program. She denied that the hugs were
sexual in nature and described them as an act of nurturing and
support. Staff 1 confirmed that she once kissed Youth A on the
8

forehead as a act of caring and nurturing. Staff 1 also advised
that some months ago the behavior of hugging and other physical
contact was addressed with her by program staff. She has stated
she has refrained from hugging or kissing any agency youth since
that time.
Allegation #2
Interview
On 07/30/2025 an interview was completed with Youth B at The
Sanctuary. He reported that Youth A advised him that she has the
personal phone number of Staff 1 and talks to her on her phone.
Youth B denied that he has personally seen Youth A and Staff 1
speak on the phone.
On 7/30/2025 an interview was held with Staff 1. She reported
that she was given access to a “go phone” from The Sanctuary in
order to have contact with residents in the program. Staff 1
confirmed that she utilized the phone to speak with Youth A when
she was not at work. When asked about the frequency of calls
she had with Youth A, she responded almost daily. Staff 1 also
confirmed that she would speak with Youth A on the phone even
when she was not at work. Staff 1 confirmed that she sometimes
had contact with other residents via the Sanctuary issued “go
phone”. During the interview, Staff 1 also showed her call log
which included missed calls from the company “Noddle’s and
Company”. Staff 1 confirmed that this is where Youth A works.
She reported that she has refrained from talking with Youth A via
telephone since her suspension. On 08/08/2025 and 08/25/2025
telephone call attempts were made to Staff 1 for follow-up
questions, however the calls were unsuccessful. Staff 1 no longer
is employed with Sanctuary.
On 08/07/2025 an interview of Youth A was completed by DCWL
Consultant 2 at The Sanctuary. Youth A reported she is not
currently connected to any former or current staff on social media.
She reported her initial contact with Staff 1 via social media began
in January 2025, but she unfriended her around April or May.
Youth A reported she is not currently communicating with Staff 1
but had in the past. Youth A also reported and showed
screenshots of Instagram messages from Staff 1. Youth A
reported Staff 1 has attempted to contact her, but she misses the
calls. She reported no physical contact with Staff 1. Youth A
reported she was told to delete text messages and other
communication between them by Staff 1. Youth A also confirmed
that she would meet with Staff 1 outside of work. She denied that
9

their was any inappropriate contact or conversation that occurred
during their contact.
On 08/07/2025 an interview of Youth D was held at The Sanctuary
by DCWL Consultant 2. Youth D reported he recently became
social media friends with Staff 1. He reported becoming friends
with her a few days prior to todays interview. Youth D was able to
show his Instagram account that confirmed he was friends with
Staff 1, however refused to allow a photo to be taken. Youth D
denied that their interactions are inappropriate. He denied meeting
Staff 1 outside of The Sanctuary for personal meet ups and
denied seeing her in the community. Youth D described Staff 1 as
very nice and is like a mother to him. Youth D reported he
obtained the social media information of Staff 1 from Youth A.
Youth D denied knowledge if Staff 1 is following and engaging
with other Sanctuary Youth on social media.
On 08/07/2025 an interview was completed with Staff 2 at The
Sanctuary by DCWL Consultant 2. She denied being social media
friends with any of the youth at Sanctuary. She further denied
knowledge of Staff 1 having telephone contact or social media
contact with youth placed at Sanctuary.
On 08/07/2025 an interview was completed with Staff 6 at The
Sanctuary by DCWL Consultant 2. Staff 6 reported she overheard
Youth D talking to Staff 1 on the phone and he was saying she
was the only person he could trust and not to tell anyone that he
was talking to her. Staff reported overhearing that Staff 1
unfriended Youth A on social media and friended Youth D out of
spite. Staff 6 denied that she is friends with any of the youth on
social media. She denied knowledge of whether or not other staff
follow youth on social media. Staff 6 reported the facility policy is
against current and ex-employees having a relationship with
residents. Staff 6 reported Staff 1 was informed she was not to
have any contact with the youth after suspension or termination,
but she is still in contact with the youth via telephone and social
media.
On 08/07/2025 an email was sent to Chief Administrator (CA) and
DHHS Specialist. A request was made for copies of the agency
policy relative to cell phone and social media use between youth
staff. CA responded and advised that the agency does not have a
specific policy that addresses telephone and social media contact
between staff and agency youth.
Documents Reviewed
10

There was no agency policy to review as the agency does not
have policy to guide staff or address issues relative to personal
telephone contact between staff and youth, nor does the agency
have a policy to address social media contact between staff and
youth.
Cell Phone Screen Photos – documented the call log of Youth A
that included incoming, outgoing and missed calls from a phone
number belonging to Staff 1.
Instagram Social Media Screen Photos – documented social
media interaction and comments between Youth A, Youth B and
Staff 1.
Lighthouse Employees Policies and Procedures – Code of
Ethical Conduct
The Code of Ethical Conduct sets forth beliefs and ethical principles and
values to which staff members and volunteers shall aspire to and by
which their actions and decisions can be judged. LIGHTHOUSE
practices a zero-tolerance policy for intentional illegal and/or unethical
behavior. Unintentional acts that may be perceived or construed as
possible illegal and/or unethical behavior will result in disciplinary action
commensurate to the act.
E. Staff-Client Relationship—Physical Conduct
Staff should not engage in physical contact with clients, including when
there is a possibility for psychological harm to the consumer as a result
of the contact (such as cradling or caressing clients). Staff members are
responsible for setting clear, appropriate, and culturally sensitive
boundaries that prohibit such physical contact.
Analysis Allegation #1:
At the conclusion of the investigation the agency was found to be
in non-compliance with the licensing rule. After interviews with
both staff and youth, it was confirmed that Staff 1 engaged in
hugging of youth and a kiss on the forehead of Youth A which is a
violation of the agency physical contact policy.
Allegation #2:
At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in non-compliance with the licensing rule as they failed to develop
policy to address telephone and social medica contact between
staff and agency youth to ensure safety of youth and integrity of
the agency program.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Rule Code &
R 400.4131 Compliance with child protection law; development
Section
of plan required.
Description
Rule 131. The licensee shall develop and implement a written plan to
assure compliance with the child protection law, 1975 PA 238, MCL
722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Agency staff failed to report concerns of abuse or neglect as
required by Child Protection Law.
Investigation Interview
On 7/17/2025 a telephone interview was held with Complainant.
I was advised that to their knowledge, The Sanctuary staff had not
made a complaint of suspected abuse or neglect regarding
concerns of Staff 1 hugging and kissing Youth A as of 7/17/2025.
On 7/18/2025 an interview was completed with Staff 2 at The
Sanctuary. She reported that she did not make a report of
suspected abuse or neglect to centralized intake regarding
concerns of Staff 1 hugging and kissing Youth A.
On 7/30/2025 an interview was completed with Program
Manager. He confirmed that he was advised of the concerns
regarding Staff 1 hugging and kissing Youth A on 7/10/2025, but
did not make a complaint as he did not assess it as abuse or
neglect.
Documents Reviewed
Lighthouse Employees Policies and Procedures - Employee
Standards F. Suspicion of Abuse and/or Neglect
All agency staff are required to report any suspicion of child or
adult neglect or abuse to the Michigan Child Abuse Hotline
immediately, or as soon as feasible. Staff must also
contemporaneously document the incident on an Incident Report.
Staff in need of assistance in filing a report can seek guidance
from the agency’s Chief Operating Officer. For more information
on when and how to report instances of abuse or neglect, please
refer to the Mandated Reporter document found as an appendix to
this manual.
DHHS 2165 – Documented that report of suspected abuse or
neglect was not made until 07/18/2025.
12

Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in non-compliance with licensing rule. A concern was expressed
regarding possible inappropriate actions between Staff 1 and
Youth A, that involved hugging and kissing. The agency failed to
immediately make a report of potential abuse or neglect to
centralized intake.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
